content.title: Noob Orientation: What You Literally See
content.content:
Rig-safe note: training rig learning only. On real installations you only open/access when safely isolated and proven dead under supervision.

When you open a typical 3-plate ceiling rose you will see **three separate terminal groups**. People call them:
- **plates** OR **terminal groups** OR (in this course) **buckets**.
They all mean the same thing: **three separate places to put wires by their job**.

You may also see:
- A **lamp flex** (short cable going to the lamp holder).
- One or more **cables** entering the rose (supply in, maybe supply out, plus a switch drop).
- **CPCs (earths)** grouped together (often in an earth terminal/connector).

Your beginner goal is simple:
1) Decide each wire’s **role** (what it does).
2) Put it into the correct **group/bucket**.

content.title: Understanding the 3-Plate System
content.content:
Safety note (training rig only): This lesson is for conceptual learning. Never open or work on real ceiling roses unless you are trained/supervised and the circuit is safely isolated and proven dead.

## 1) What is a ceiling rose?
If you’ve never seen one: a ceiling rose is **two things in one**.
- A **junction point** where several cables join together.
- The **connection point** for the lamp holder (the light).

That’s why a rose can look crowded: it’s not just ‘a light connector’ — it’s also where the circuit continues.

## 2) What “loop-in” means (plain English)
Many lighting circuits go: Consumer unit → Light 1 → Light 2 → Light 3 …

**Loop-in** means the main supply is joined at each ceiling rose and then continues (‘loops’) onward to the next light point.

At a typical rose in the middle of a run, you often see:
- a cable bringing supply **in**
- a cable taking supply **out** to the next light
- a cable going to the switch (the **switch drop**)
- the lamp flex (to the lamp holder)

## 3) The three terminal groups (three “buckets”)
A 3-plate rose is easiest if you imagine **three labelled buckets**. Each conductor must go in the correct bucket.

### Plate A — Neutrals group
This group is for **all neutrals joined together**.
Typical roles you’ll see joined here:
- Neutral from supply **in**
- Neutral to supply **out** (if there is a next light)
- Lamp neutral (from lamp flex)

Neutral is normally **not switched** in a standard 1-way lighting circuit.

### Plate B — Permanent lives (loop) group
This group is for the lives that are **permanently live when the circuit is energised**.
Typical roles you’ll see joined here:
- Live from supply **in**
- Live to supply **out** (if there is a next light)
- Live feed **to the switch** (down the switch drop)

### Plate C — Switched live group
This group is for the live that comes **back from the switch**.
Typical roles you’ll see joined here:
- Switched live return (from the switch drop)
- Lamp live (from lamp flex)

## 4) The switch (simple mental picture)
A 1-way switch is like a bridge in the live path.
- One conductor takes a **permanent live feed down** to the switch.
- One conductor brings a **switched live back** to the lamp.

So the lamp only gets power when the switch ‘connects’ the feed to the return.

## 5) Tiny colour anchor (don’t rely on colour alone)
Modern colours you often see on training rigs:
- **Blue = Neutral**
- **Brown = Live**
- **Green/Yellow = CPC (Earth)**

Important: colours help, but **role + correct grouping** is what matters.

questions.questionText: What are the two main functions of a ceiling rose?
expectedAnswer: Junction point and lamp connection point
It joins circuit cables and connects the lamp
questions.hint: It joins cables and provides the connection point for the light.

questions.questionText: Which terminal group would be live when the circuit is energised even if the light switch is OFF?
questions.hint: It's the group that feeds the switch and loops onward.

questions.questionText: Is the neutral wire usually connected to the switch in a standard loop-in circuit?
expectedAnswer: No, the switch normally interrupts the live
questions.hint: In a basic loop-in circuit, the switch interrupts the live path.

questions.questionText: Why is the lamp's live kept separate from the permanent live (loop) group?
expectedAnswer: So the switch can control the lamp live
So the lamp only becomes live when the switched live returns
If it was in the loop group the lamp would be permanently live / always on
questions.hint: If the lamp live was in the permanent live group, the lamp would be live all the time.

content.scenario: Identify the wiring mistake for a ceiling rose:

options.text: Lamp neutral goes with other neutrals
Lamp live goes into Permanent Live

content.explanation: Putting the lamp live into Permanent Live makes the light stay on constantly.

content.title: Common Mistakes (Beginner Traps)
content.content:
These are the mistakes that cause most confusion (and on real systems, can be dangerous). Learn them as **warnings**.

1) **Putting the lamp live into the Permanent Live (Loop) group**
- Result: the lamp can become live all the time (switch no longer controls it).

2) **Mixing up Permanent Live and Switched Live**
- Permanent live feeds the switch.
- Switched live comes back from the switch and feeds the lamp.

3) **Forgetting the lamp neutral goes with the other neutrals**
- Lamp neutral belongs in the Neutral group with the circuit neutrals.

4) **Treating the switch drop as ‘one live, one neutral’**
- In loop-in switching, the switch drop typically carries **two live conductors (feed down + switched return)**, not a neutral.

5) **Leaving CPCs (earths) not properly joined/parked**
- Even on a training rig, keep CPCs organised: joined together and connected to the correct earth point/terminal if present.

Key habit: Always sort conductors by **role** (what they do) and then place them into the correct terminal group.

content.title: Worked Example (I Do): The 3 Buckets in One Minute
content.given:
Training rig (concept): You have a ceiling rose, a cable bringing power IN, a cable going to the SWITCH, and a short cable going to the LAMP. (Sometimes there is also a cable taking power OUT to the next light.)

Goal: Put each wire into the correct bucket so the switch controls the lamp.

steps.description: Bucket 1: Neutrals — find the wires that are neutral.
steps.result: Put ALL neutrals together in the Neutral bucket: supply neutral(s) + lamp neutral.

steps.description: Bucket 2: Loop (Permanent Live) — find the wires that must stay ‘always live’ to feed the switch and continue the circuit.
steps.result: Put permanent lives together in the Loop bucket: supply live(s) + the wire that goes down to the switch (the switch feed).

steps.description: Bucket 3: Switched Live — find the wire that comes BACK from the switch and only becomes live when the switch is ON.
steps.result: Put the switch return together with the lamp live in the Switched Live bucket: switch return + lamp live.

steps.description: Earths (CPCs) — keep them together and safe.
steps.result: Join/park all CPCs together and connect to the rose earth terminal/connector if provided.

steps.description: One quick sanity check (the ‘switch actually controls it’ check).
steps.result: Lamp live must NOT be in the Loop bucket. Lamp live must be in the Switched Live bucket so the switch can turn it on/off.

content.notes: Beginner rule: Don’t panic about cable names. Just do the same 3 questions every time: (1) Which are the neutrals? (2) Which are the always-live lives feeding the switch? (3) Which one comes back from the switch to feed the lamp?

content.title: Guided Practice (We Do): Same 3 Buckets, You Point Them Out
content.problem:
Training rig scenario (concept): You are looking at a ceiling rose.
You can see:
- a cable bringing power IN
- a cable going to the SWITCH (switch drop)
- a cable going to the LAMP (lamp flex)
Sometimes you may also have a cable taking power OUT to the next light.

Answer using bucket names only (Neutral / Loop / Switched Live).

steps.hint: Supply neutral(s) and lamp neutral all join together.

steps.prompt: Which bucket gets the wire that FEEDS the switch (goes down to the switch)?
steps.hint: It must be permanent live to feed the switch.

steps.prompt: Which bucket gets the wire that RETURNS from the switch (only live when the switch is ON)?
steps.hint: This is the one that comes back to feed the lamp live.

steps.prompt: Which bucket does the lamp LIVE join into so the switch controls the lamp?
steps.hint: Lamp live must NOT sit in the permanent live loop.

steps.prompt: Which bucket would be the most dangerous place to accidentally put the lamp live (because it can make it permanently fed)?
steps.hint: That bucket is ‘always live’ when energised.

steps.prompt: What do you do with CPCs (earths) on a training rig conceptually?
expectedAnswer: Join them together and terminate/park safely
steps.hint: Earths stay continuous and are grouped/terminated neatly.

content.title: Your Turn (You Do): Quick Sort Drills

questions.questionText: In the middle of a loop-in circuit, list the three neutral roles you’d expect to be grouped together in the Neutral terminal (don’t worry about colours).
expectedAnswer: neutral in, neutral out, lamp neutral
supply neutral in, supply neutral out, lamp neutral
neutral from supply in, neutral to next light, neutral to lamp
questions.hint: Think: supply in, supply out (to next light), and the lamp connection.

questions.questionText: Which specific conductor returns from the switch to the ceiling rose to power the lamp when the switch is ON?
questions.hint: It becomes live only when the switch is ON.

questions.questionText: A student puts the lamp live into the Permanent Live (Loop) group. What is the likely result (in plain English)?
expectedAnswer: The lamp could be live all the time
The lamp would not be controlled by the switch
The light may stay on / become permanently fed
questions.hint: What happens if the lamp is connected to an always-live group?

questions.questionText: What is the name of the wiring method where the main supply continues from rose to rose (light point to light point)?
Connection (Level 2): Describe the live path in one sentence: from the Permanent Live (Loop) group, through the switch drop, to the lamp.
expectedAnswer: Permanent live feeds down to the switch and returns as switched live to feed the lamp live
Loop live goes to the switch, then switched live returns to the lamp
questions.hint: Use the words: feed down, return back, switched live.

questions.questionText: Synthesis (Level 3, 3–4 sentences): Explain why a ceiling rose at the end of a circuit has fewer conductors than one in the middle, and name the exact roles that are missing.
questions.expectedAnswer: A middle light has to pass the supply onwards, so it has a supply IN cable and a supply OUT cable. The end light has no next light to feed, so the supply OUT live, supply OUT neutral (and its CPC) are missing. The rose still needs a feed to the switch and a switched return to the lamp, so those roles remain. That is why the end-of-circuit rose looks less crowded.
questions.hint: Focus on what disappears when there is no 'next light'.

content.title: Spaced Review (rose-relevant)

questions.questionText: In a standard 1-way lighting circuit, which conductor does the switch interrupt: Line (live) or Neutral?
questions.hint: The goal is that the lamp isn’t fed when the switch is OFF.

questions.questionText: Name the three terminal groups in a 3-plate ceiling rose.
questions.hint: Think: neutrals bucket, always-live join, and switch-controlled return.

questions.questionText: In one sentence, what is the purpose of the CPC (earth) in a lighting circuit?
questions.expectedAnswer: To provide an earth path for fault current so protective devices can operate and keep exposed metal parts safe.
questions.hint: It’s a safety path, not part of normal current flow.

questions.questionText: In loop-in switching, does the switch drop usually carry a neutral?
questions.expectedAnswer: No — it typically carries a permanent live feed down and a switched live return back.
questions.hint: Think: feed down, return back (both are live conductors by role).

content.notes: Reinforcing the core ceiling rose mental model and the common beginner traps.
